heading: dow surges on factory data
subheading: as the blue chips head toward a new record, tech stocks are once again in the doghouse as investors throw their money at the pillars of heavy industry. by david lazarus.
author: david lazarus
text: blue-chip stocks were back in the driver's seat monday as some new manufacturing numbers temporarily eased worries about inflation. investors continued to shower affection on previously neglected heavy-industry concerns amid hopes for a global economic recovery. the dow jones industrial average jumped 150.91 points to 10939.95 in midafternoon trading. money was flowing into "cyclical" shares such as goodyear tire & rubber (gt) and international paper (ip).tech stocks, which had regained a modicum of buoyancy on friday, were once again lagging their factory-floor cousins. the wired index shed 4.35 to 643.63, and the nasdaq composite index was 16.77 lower at 2526.08. the s&p 500 was up 7.20 at 1342.38.after opening on an anxious note, wall street found its footing when the national association of purchasing management released its index of manufacturing activity. the index for april declined 1.5 percentage points from the previous month to 52.8. an increase to 55 had been expected.what does this mean? it means that the white-hot us economy might not be set to boil over, as recent gdp numbers suggested, and that inflation isn't yet a going concern.or so some think. bill meehan, chief market analyst at cantor fitzgerald, noted that while the latest napm stats were rosier than anticipated, any index number greater than 50 is still taken as a sign of expansion in the industrial sector, thus reflecting a persistently robust economy. this will be very much on the minds of federal reserve pooh-bahs when they hold their next get-together on 18 may."it's fairly clear," meehan warned, "that as the global economy starts to recover, the fed will take back one of its rate cuts."and you just know that wouldn't sit well with investors. expect sentiment to grow increasingly skittish as the next fed meeting draws near.meantime, the courtship dance surrounding cable operator mediaone group holds fascination for market players, not least because of the stellar cast involved. over the weekend, mediaone decided to accept at&t's us$54-billion buyout offer, thus spurning a rival $48-billion bid from comcast. but this is all just a formality. comcast now has until thursday to come up with a counteroffer, and it should be interesting to see what, if anything, they manage to put on the table.comcast reportedly is negotiating with both america online and microsoft about ways to sweeten its deal. while aol might enjoy securing high-speed access to subscribers' homes, few believe that bill gates wants to go kicking dirt onto at&t's shoes just to gain a greater toehold in the cable world. in any case, it's a sure bet that lawyers from all sides are racking up some big-time fees this week dickering over possible terms.at&t (t) is the clear winner so far, with its stock advancing 69 cents to $51.19. mediaone (umg) eased $2 to $79.63, while comcast (cmcsa) was up $1.50 at $64.38. aol (aol) dropped $6.81 to $135.94, and microsoft (msft) was $1.94 lower at $79.38.
